awd_titl_txt: III: Small: Facilitating Search in the High-Dimensional Space of Molecular Interactions
awd_abstract_narration:
The binding of proteins (receptors) to small molecules (ligands) is often the underlying mechanism behind biological processes such as immune response and cell signaling. Understanding how receptors and ligands bind is fundamental to explaining these biological phenomena, and for innovative drug discovery and design. The exploration  will include designing methods for analyzing binding pathways and kinetics, focusing on the extraction of computational features from multiple user runs. The product of this will be used in outreach activities performed by the PIs in K-12 schools and local museums. In addition to being potentially applicable in cutting-edge computational biophysics research, the resources will also provide the ideal interface to teach the public about molecular interactions and the role they play in biological processes such as allergic reactions.

This award will develop methods for simulating binding of biomolecules via an interactive collaborative interface that harnesses and integrates multi-user exploration of the energetic landscape through haptic interfaces. This will address the current limitations of molecular docking simulations by facilitating search in the high-dimensional energetic landscape of molecular docking.  Results will include a crowd-sourced high-dimensional dataset of energies and molecular configuration from which to extract biophysical properties of binding events. The long-term objective of the work is to develop a fast, accurate system to aid drug discovery by identifying docking pathways and ligand-receptor conformations using crowd-sourced information.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
This project consisted of understanding how proteins and ligands bind and interact while navigating the complex energetic relationship between the two molecules, where a binding site represents the lowest energy state of the molecule. We developed an Interactive Molecular Docking software (DockAnywhere), which exploits users' intuition to determine docked configurations of ligand and receptor from visualizing the molecules in 3d and using input devices. We used both human generated data obtained with an interactive molecular docking program and simulated data to understand how these molecules interact with each other, and to compare the impact of user results with automated results. This work also allowed us to understand how humans and computers can collaborate towards accomplishing a complex task. 

We used ideas from how humans interact with computers and robotics to analyze our data. Users of the Interactive Molecular Docking software were presented with different molecules involved in disease shown under different conditions. We performed extensive statistical analysis to separate the different environments and identify the relevant software features that impacted performance. We explored whether molecular coloring based on physical properties could help guide users, and we showed that it was possible within certain conditions. For instance, if molecules are portrayed in different colors based on whether the forces between the ligand and receptor attract or repel, we found in some cases users could explore better the interactions between the molecules. We also explored ligand flexibility and how a ligand can move and change shape as it approaches the receptor based on the energy between the two molecules. We found that users contribute in very different ways to the data, exploring different parts of the molecule and moving the ligand in distinct ways. A mobile version of the Interactive Molecular Docking software was also developed to enable crowdsourced data collection. The capabilities of the mobile version and the desktop version of the software were essentially the same, but a mobile interface limits the possibilities of user interaction with the molecule, requiring creative solutions for buttons and gestures on the screen.

We brought both the desktop and mobile versions of the Interactive Molecular Docking software to multiple local museums and university outreach events for demonstration to the public. Children of all ages and adults were able to learn about molecular docking and its important role in drug discovery. Through these demonstrations, we were able to communicate to this audience how computer science can help solve this problem with improved search algorithms in complex spaces and show how humans and computers can work together to solve hard problems.


Last Modified: 04/10/2024
Modified by: Bruna D Jacobson
